newsitem.title: USA: USDA's Glickman writes Hill leaders on ethanol.
newsitem.headline: USDA's Glickman writes Hill leaders on ethanol.

text.p: U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman Thursday sent a letter to congressional leaders underlining the Clinton administration's support for the ethanol tax break.

"The Clinton Administration is strongly committed to the continued growth and development of the U.S. ethanol industry and opposes efforts currently underway in Congress to repeal the federal excise tax exemption for ethanol," he said in a June 12 letter to Rep. Newt Gingrich, Georgia Republican.
Identical letters were sent to five other top lawmakers.
House tax writer Bill Archer, Texas Republican, has proposed paring down the tax break for users of corn-based ethanol fuel and eliminating it in the year 2000.
Glickman said repealing the exemption would cost American farmers billions of dollars in lost income and displace thousands of jobs.

He is the second senior administration official to speak out against Archer's proposal. On Wednesday, Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin said the White House supported the ethanol tax break and earlier this year had proposed extending it.
